Regina Elisabeta Bucharest 030018 Romania In this work, the structural and bifunctional catalytic properties of MgNi(Cu)Al layered double hydroxides (LDH) with different molar ratios between the cations were studied. The LDH materials were prepared by co-precipitation and were characterized using X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-Ray diffraction (XRD), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFT), diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (DR-UV-VIS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption-desorption and acidity-basicity measurements. They were tested in a one-pot cascade oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction used to synthesize 2-Benzoyl-3-phenylprop-2-enenitrile also known as 2-Benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA). This involved the benzyl alcohol (BnOH) oxidation under an oxygen atmosphere followed by the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with 3-oxo-3-phenylpropanenitrile also known as benzoyl acetonitrile (BzACN). Three different non-polar solvents, i.e., toluene, benzene and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (mesitylene), were used as reaction media. For the LDH catalysts containing both nickel and copper, the alcohol conversion and BPA yield increased with Ni/Cu molar ratio. The acid-base properties of the solids and the nature of the solvent strongly influence the reaction performance. Still, due to their anion-exchange properties, they belong to the anionic clay group [1]. The following general formula describes the LDH: [M2+ 1-xM3+ x(OH)2][Am− x/m·nH2O], where M2+ and M3+ are divalent and trivalent metal cations, respectively, connected through hydroxyl groups forming the cationic layers, Am− represents the compensating anions interlayered together with n molecules of water, while x is the charge density or the anionic exchange capacity [1]. Their lamellar structure with versatile interlayer zone, rheological properties, colloidal behavior, variable chemical composition, and layer charge density determined the significant impact of LDH in many fields of applications, but mainly in catalysis [1]. The most recurrent LDH solid consists only of Mg and Al, which can easily be replaced by many metallic cations having the appropriate valence state and ionic radius [2]. Mg can be isomorphically substituted by all the divalent cations with similar ionic radius and prefer an octahedral configuration, besides Cu, which can give LDH-type compounds only when mixed with different divalent cations, such as Co, Mn etc. [2]. According to the literature, the synthesis of CuAl-LDH is problematic due to the following issues: i) at a pH value of ca. 5, isolated hydroxide compounds, such as Cu(OH)2 or Al(OH)3 may be obtained, and ii) the Jahn-Teller effect of the copper cation when hydroxyl anions octahedrally surround it can alter the development of the lamellar structure reducing the electrostatic interaction between the brucite-type layers and the anions present in the interlayer region. The Jahn-Teller effect of the copper cations can also lead to the occurrence of malachite or gerhardtite side-phases [2–5]. However, it is possible to obtain Cu-containing LDH by attenuating the impact of the Jahn-Teller effect of Cu2+ using a second divalent cation, M2+, at a molar ratio Cu2+/M2+ equal to or lower than 1 [4]. When Ni2+ species replace the Mg2+ cations present in the brucite-like layers, they are usually evenly distributed in the layer [6,7]. The Ni/Al molar ratio influences the stability of the LDH catalysts containing Ni and Al cations. A molar ratio between 1.17-2 [8] enables the formation of stable LDH. Neat NiAl-LDH can be synthesized only when 0.2 ≤ x ≤ 0.33, where x is the charge density, which corresponds to a Ni/Al molar ratio between 2 and 4 [9]. When the values of x are out of the above-mentioned range, the LDH will also contain Ni(OH)2 or bayerite [9]. The pH value also plays a significant role in the synthesis of Ni-Al hydrotalcites, influencing their morphology [8]. It has been found that the Ni-containing LDH has higher thermal stability than the Cu-containing LDH, which can only operate in reactions at temperatures up to 250°C [10,11] because at higher temperatures, their activity will dramatically decrease due to copper sintering. Due to their potential economic uses in the synthesis of fine chemicals, fragrant compounds, and in the pharmaceutical sector, both oxidation [12–14] and condensation [15,16] reactions are of great interest. The advanced oxidation reaction is also of interest for the removal of hazardous pollutants from water [17,18]. Nowadays, finding innovative solutions to stop or, at least, to decrease the pollution that occurs in the chemical industry has become a priority. Multistep reactions are among the processes that imply a higher demand for “green” catalytic alternatives. Solving this issue by using tandem or one-pot cascade reactions represents an environmentally friendly solution that can reduce waste production and untangle convoluted synthetic routes [19]. Various catalysts have been used for cascade reactions; however, many of them presented some serious inconsistencies, such as high cost of production or the need to use additives during the multistep processes [20]. Some of these catalysts were discussed in our previous article [20]. In 2017, Zhou and coll. [21] reported a bifunctional NiGa LDH catalyst for the aerobic oxidation-condensation tandem reaction between aromatic alcohols and active methylene compounds in different solvents. Even though NiGa LDH has been a good bifunctional catalyst for this type of reaction, it is not attractive for industrial application since gallium has a low abundance in nature and its price is high. The current work focuses on the synthesis by co-precipitation of cheaper alternative catalysts, such as multicationic MgNi(Cu)Al-layered double hydroxides with different molar ratios between the cations, and their use in the one-pot cascade oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction for obtaining 2-benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA), an important tyrosinase inhibitor which do not display cytotoxic effects [8] (Scheme 1 ). Thus, the target product was synthesized through the aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol, followed by the Knoevenagel condensation of the obtained benzaldehyde with benzoylacetonitrile (BzACN). The reactions were performed in three different solvents: toluene, benzene, and mesitylene. Notably, 2-benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA) and its derivatives, (E)-2-benzoyl-3-(substituted phenyl) acrylonitriles, which possess a linear β-phenyl-α,β-unsaturated carbonyl scaffold, have been intensively used for anti-tyrosinase activity and melanogenesis [8]. Thus, the current paper aims to open up new perspectives in the rational design of efficient bifunctional catalytic systems for the organic synthesis. On the other hand, the development of a highly efficient catalytic material for the aerobic oxidation of alcohols to their corresponding carbonyl compounds in the absence of any additives is particularly attractive for the synthetic and industrial chemistry [22]. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O, Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O, Al(NO3)3∙9H2O, NaOH, Na2CO3 (chemical purity grade, purchased from Merck) 2.2 Synthesis of Mg1.2NiaCubAl(OH)6(CO3)0.5 LDH with a + b = 0.8 Three Mg1.2NiaCubAl(OH)6(CO3)0.5 solids with different Ni/Cu mol ratios, a + b = 0.8 and M2+/M3+ = 2, were prepared via the co-precipitation method, which implies the mixing of two different solutions at a constant pH value of 10. The first solution, solution A, contains the precursor metallic salts, namely Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O, Cu(NO3)2∙3H2O, Mg(NO3)2∙6H2O, Al(NO3)3∙9H2O having the total concentration of the cations of 1.5 M, respecting the fixed molar ratios. The second one, solution B, is prepared by dissolving NaOH and Na2CO3 in distilled water at a concentration of 1.2 M NaOH and 0.9 M Na2CO3, respectively. The precipitation reactor placed on a stirring plate was first filled with 100 mL of distilled water. After the pH value was adjusted to 10 using the basic solution (solution B), the two solutions A and B were added dropwise simultaneously under intense stirring at room temperature. Once the two solutions were mixed, the precipitation reactor was transferred to a hotplate stirrer, letting the obtained precipitate age at 75°C for 18 h. The precipitate was then filtered and washed with distilled water until the conductivity of the washing water was below 100 μS/cm. The final step consisted in drying the solids in an oven at 90°C for 24 h. The following three compositions were prepared in this way: Mg1.2Ni0.6Cu0.2Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5, Mg1.2Ni0.4Cu0.4Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5 and Mg1.2Ni0.2Cu0.6Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5. They were denoted as HT-Mg1.2Ni0.6Cu0.2Al, HT-Mg1.2Ni0.4Cu0.4Al and HT-Mg1.2Ni0.2Cu0.6Al, respectively. The exact amounts of the reagents used to prepare each solid are specified in the SI file. 2.3 Synthesis of Mg0.8NicCudAl(OH)6(CO3)0.5 LDH with c + d = 1.2 Three Mg0.8NicCudAl(OH)6(CO3)0.5 solids with different Ni/Cu ratios, but with c + d = 1.2 and M2+/M3+ = 2, were also prepared using the co-precipitation method, which was thoroughly described above. The solutions A and B were mixed, and the obtained precipitate was further washed, filtered and dried as described in the previous case. The following three compositions were prepared: Mg0.8Ni0.8Cu0.4Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5, Mg0.8Ni0.6Cu0.6Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5 and Mg0.8Ni0.4Cu0.8Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5, denoted as HT-Mg0.8Ni0.8Cu0.4Al, HT-Mg0.8Ni0.6Cu0.6Al and HT-Mg0.8Ni0.4Cu0.8Al, respectively. The exact amounts of the reagents used to prepare each solid are specified in the SI file. 2.4 Synthesis of LDH solids containing only one of the divalent transition-metal cations, namely Ni2Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5 and Cu2Al(OH)6(CO3)0.5 To check the existence of a Ni-Cu synergistic effect, two other solids with the same M2+/Al3+ ratio containing only one of the divalent transition-metal cations (Ni or Cu) were synthesized using the above-described co-precipitation method. They were denoted as HT-Ni2Al and HT-Cu2Al. The exact amounts of the reagents used for their preparation are specified in the SI file. 3 Materials characterization The characterization of the LDH solids was performed using a battery of techniques, such as powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption at 77 K, basicity and acidity measurements, diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform (DRIFT) and diffuse reflectance UV-Vis (DR-UV-Vis) spectroscopies. The X-ray diffractograms were recorded using a Panalytical X'Pert θ/2θ diffractometer equipped with an Xcelerator detector having automatic divergence slits and CuKα radiation (40 kV, 40 mA, λ = 0.15418 nm). Cu-beta radiation was removed using a nickel filter foil. The measurements were performed at 0.32 °/min. The samples were mounted on silicon zero background holders. The peak profiles were fitted with the Pseudo-Voigt function using the HighScore Plus software package (Panalytical). The phase identification was done by using the PDF-4+ database (2021) of the International Center of Diffraction Data (ICDD). The X-ray fluorescence data have been collected using a Panalytical Epsilon 1 spectrometer operated with an Ag X-ray source. The total number of acid sites was determined by pyridine adsorption using the DRIFT spectra recorded on a FT/IR-4700 Jasco spectrometer (Tokyo, Japan). The procedure was thoroughly described in our previous article [20]. The total number of base sites was quantitatively determined by irreversible adsorption of an organic acid, namely the acrylic acid, having a pKa of 4.2, using a JASCO V650 UV-Vis spectrometer. Approximately 0.05 g of each material were added in cylindrical brown glass vials, then 10 ml of a freshly prepared solution of acrylic acid in cyclohexane (1 M) was added over the solids and the vials were sealed and shaken for 2 h at room temperature. The sorption experiments were carried out at the wavelength of maximum absorption (λmax, nm) of acrylic acid (λmax = 225 nm), in the concentration range where the Beer-Lambert law is valid. DRIFTS spectra of the LDH materials were obtained using a Jasco FT/IR 4700 spectrometer having a PIKE accessory for diffuse reflectance. The spectra were collected in the spectral range 4000–400 cm−1, with a scanning speed of 128 scans min−1 and a resolution of 4 cm−1 using KBr as background. The diffuse reflectance UV-VIS spectra were recorded on a JASCO V650 UV-VIS spectrometer using spectralon as a white reference. The adsorption/desorption isotherms were recorded on an ASAP2020 equipment from Micromeritics, USA, in a nitrogen atmosphere, at 77 K. The samples were outgassed overnight at 22°C before the measurements. The scanning electron microscopy (SEM) analysis was performed using a Hitachi SU8230 microscope (Hitachi, Tokyo, Japan) at an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Before the analysis, the solids were covered with a 9-nm-thick layer of gold, using the Quorum Q150T ES turbomolecular pumped coater (Quorum Technologies, London, UK). 4 Catalytic tests The catalytic tests were performed according to the method described in our previous paper [20]. Practically, the one-pot cascade oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction (Scheme 1) was carried out in a 100 mL Büchi miniclave (from Buchiglas (Büchi AG) Uster, Switzerland) where 1 mmol of benzyl alcohol (BnOH) was mixed with 10 mL of solvent (toluene, benzene or mesitylene) and 1 g of catalyst (ca. 10 wt. % of the reaction mixture). The mixture was stirred under 1 atm of O2 and heated at 80°C using a glycerin bath. After 6 h of oxidation, 1.2 mmol of benzoylacetonitrile (BzACN) dissolved in 3 mL of solvent (toluene, benzene or mesitylene) was added to the existing mixture to start the condensation step leading to the formation of the final product, i.e., 2-benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA). The condensation step was continued under stirring and 1 atm of argon at 80°C for 19 h. At the end of the reaction, the catalyst was separated by filtration and washed with acetonitrile. The organic phase was analyzed on a GC-MS (Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 SE instrument, Shimadzu, Kyoto, Japan) equipped with an HP-5MS capillary column (30 m x 0.25 mm x 0.25 μm) from Agilent. Highly pure He (99.999 %) was used as a carrier gas. The alcohol conversion was calculated using the following formula: C o n v . ( % ) = n B n O H 0 − n B n O H n B n O H 0 × 100 where n B n O H 0 and n B n O H are the initial and final (unreacted) number of moles of benzyl alcohol, respectively. Because, according to the overall reaction, one mol of alcohol leads to one mol of desired product, i.e., 2-benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA), the yield was calculated as follows: Y i e l d t o B P A ( % ) = n B P A n B n O H 0 × 100 where n B P A is the number of moles of BPA formed in the tandem reaction. 5 Results and discussion 5.1 Catalysts characterization The cationic composition of the LDH solids determined by XRF together with the M/Al atomic ratios (M = Mg, Ni and/or Cu) can be seen in Table 1 . First, these results confirm the chemical modification of the layered double hydroxides with Ni and Cu cations. The obtained values indicate that the Mg/Al ratio is slightly smaller than expected, probably due to the incomplete precipitation of magnesium during the synthesis step. This effect is more discernable for the samples with a smaller amount of Mg and greater amount of Cu, i.e., HT-Mg0.8Ni0.6Cu0.6Al and HT-Mg0.8Ni0.4Cu0.8Al. For the latter and for HT-Cu2Al, the Cu/Al atomic ratios are slightly higher than the theoretical values, while they are close to the calculated values for the other samples. At the same time, the Ni/Al atomic ratios are close to the theoretical values for all the Mg-containing samples, being slightly higher for HT-Ni2Al sample. The results of the acidity and basicity measurements are tabulated in Table 2 . It can be observed that all the samples present both acidic and basic sites, but as expected, the number of acid sites is sensibly lower than that of base sites. In both Mg-containing series, i.e., HT-Mg1.2NiaCubAl and HT-Mg0.8NicCudAl, the total number of base sites increases, while that of acid sites decreases with increasing the Cu content at the expense of Ni. The unexpectedly high basicity of the HT-Cu2Al sample is thought to be caused by the XRD-detected Cu2(CO3)(OH)2-malachite side-phase. Since Ni2+ (1.91) and Cu2+ (1.91) have identical electronegativity values on the Pauling scale [23], the Jahn-Teller effect of copper cations is crucial for the catalytic activity [4]. This leads to distortion of the octahedral coordination structure of the LDH, which raises the surface energy and, as a result, an increase of the catalytic activity is expected. Additionally, the isomorphic substitution in the brucite-like layer octahedral locations, which is influenced by the ionic radius of Cu2+ (0.73 Å), which is close to that of Mg2+ (0.72 Å) and larger than that of Ni2+ (0.69 Å), should be taken into consideration [24]. The specific surface area, the pore volume, and the pore size of the prepared samples are presented in Table 2. Their corresponding adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions are shown in Fig. 1 and Fig. S1, respectively. According to the IUPAC classification, the solids reveal type IV isotherms specific to mesoporous materials. All the MgNiCuAl-type compounds present an H2b-type hysteresis loop characteristic for narrow slit-like mesopores which can present a fine bottleneck with one side almost closed or double side open [25,26]. Additionally, these samples frequently combine cylinder-shaped pores with parallel plate-shaped pores [26]. This resemblance can be associated to the similar aspect of the SEM images corresponding to the samples with quaternary composition. The HT-Ni2Al exhibits an H1-type hysteresis loop specific to a narrow range of uniform mesopores [25]. The type H1 loop is also associated with materials that agglomerate, forming spheres spread in a uniform array [27]. This information is confirmed by the SEM image (Fig. 5) of the HT-Ni2Al solid. The HT-Cu2Al presents an H3-type loop given by aggregates of plate-like particles, as confirmed by the SEM images (Fig. 5). The XRD patterns of the Mg-containing materials, i.e., HT-Mg1.2NiaCubAl and HT-Mg0.8NicCudAl, (Fig. 2 ) have the characteristics of a typical well crystallized single hydrotalcite-like phase, with sharp, symmetric and intense diffraction lines at low 2θ angular values and less intense, asymmetric lines, at higher 2θ values (ICDD card no. 01-089-5434). HT-Ni2Al pattern matches the Ni,Al-LDH phase (ICDD card no. 04-018-1341), while in the HT-Cu2Al pattern, besides the Cu,Al-LDH phase (ICDD card no. 00-037-0630), lines corresponding to a monoclinic Cu2(CO3)(OH)2-malachite side-phase (ICDD card no. 00-056-0001) can be identified. All the reflections of the layered phase were indexed to a hexagonal lattice with an R3m rhombohedral symmetry. Lattice parameters a (average distance between two cations in the layers, a = 2d110) and c (three times the distance between two layers, c = 3d003) were calculated from their (110) and (003) diffraction lines and were gathered in Table 3 . The sensitivity of parameter a to the nature of layer cations is exposed in Fig. S2. Based on the proportion of the metal components, as revealed by XRF measurements (Table 1), and on their Shannon ionic radii: 0.72, 0.73, 0.69 and 0.535 Å for Mg2+, Cu2+, Ni2+ and Al3+, respectively, an average ionic radius of the layer cations, r(Me,Al), was determined for each solid (Table 3). Indeed, as shown in Fig. S2, the a lattice parameter values are proportional to the cationic composition of the solids, except for the HT-Cu2Al solid, which contains a side-phase (malachite). The correlation of the a-parameter value with the apparent composition of the ternary LDH emphasizes the effective substitution of the Mg2+ by Ni2+ and Cu2+ and is an indication that other non-LDH phases are absent. The c lattice parameter values, determined by the nature and orientation of the interlayer anions, are nearly identical for all materials, except for HT-Cu2Al. This can be explained taking into consideration that, on the one hand, the Me/Al atomic ratios are roughly the same for all the solids and, on the other hand, as the DRIFT spectra indicate (Fig. 3 ), only carbonates, OH groups and water are present in the interlayer spaces. Due to the presence of the malachite impurity phase, the smaller Cu/Al atomic ratio of the Cu,Al-LDH phase in the HT-Cu2Al solid leads to stronger electrostatic interactions of the layers with the interlayer anions and stronger hydrogen bonding with the interlayer water molecules and, hence, to a smaller c parameter value. Crystallite sizes along the normal to the layers, D003, and in the plane of the layers, D110, were calculated with the Scherrer formula using the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the (003) and (110) diffraction lines, respectively, the values obtained being tabulated in Table 3. As expected, the largest crystalline domain sizes of the brucite-like layer are attained in the solids with only one divalent transition-metal cation, i.e., HT-Ni2Al and HT-Cu2Al, respectively. For the quaternary hydrotalcite-like materials, there is an evident disorder effect due to the isomorphous substitution of Mg2+ by Ni2+ and Cu2+, in particular for the HT-Mg0.8NicCudAl series characterized by a higher degree of substitution [28–30]. The brucite-like sheet disorder induces a smaller long-range order along the c-axis due mainly to the presence of stacking faults, reflected in the D003 values, and to turbostratic distortions, reflected by the large and asymmetric broadness of the (0kl) reflections in the medium 2-theta angular domain. Table 3 shows the values of FWHM of the (015) reflection as a marker of turbostraticity effect. Linear relationships between the crystalline domain sizes, i.e., D003 vs D001, on one hand, and between the turbostraticity (FWHM015) and the crystalline domain size inside the brucite-like layer (D110), on the other hand, can be observed (Figs. S3 and S4). Stacking faults and turbostratic distortion have been associated with a mismatch in the geometries of layers and interlayer anions, which prevents an ideal packing of the layers or local distortions within slabs due to the microstrain arising from the distribution of electrostatic charges [31,32]. This is likely the case of the quaternary hydrotalcite-like solids. These results are to be correlated with the textural properties of the as-prepared materials: relative large surface areas (Table 2), and the proportionality of the D003 values, indicative of the long-range order along the layers stacking direction, with the pore volumes (Fig. S5). Notably, as previously mentioned, the HT-Cu2Al material is apart due to the Jahn-Teller distortion effect of copper, which is responsible for the presence of a side-phase and a different LDH-phase pattern shape with preferred orientation in the c-direction. This is consistent with the acicular forms observed in the SEM image (Fig. 5). On the other hand, it is noteworthy that the presence of some amorphous phase could not be completely ruled out. The intensity of (110) reflection, related only to the brucite-like layer, is an indicative of the amount of LDH crystalline phase, which includes ordered stacked layers as well as delaminated layers. The amount of amorphous material is expected to affect the textural properties by its deposition inside the pores. Indeed, a linear correlation has been found between the intensity of the (110) reflection and the pore volume: the HT-Ni2Al material, which contains the least amorphous phase exhibits the highest pore volume (Fig. S6). To determine the nature and the symmetry of the anions present in the interlayer space and the existence of any impurity phases, the DRIFT spectra shown in Fig. 3 were recorded. All the hydrotalcite-like samples showed an intense broad band between ca. 3800 and 3000 cm−1 attributed to the hydroxyl stretching mode characteristic for the layer OH groups and interlayered water molecules. A weak shoulder around 3000 cm−1 appeared in all the cases ascribed to the OH stretching mode resulting from the interaction through hydrogen bonds between the water molecules and carbonate anions present in the interlayer region [2]. The weak band at around 1600 cm−1 is specific for the bending mode of water molecules. The relatively sharp, intense band at about 1000 cm−1 is attributed to mode ν3 antisymmetric stretching of interlayer carbonate. The results confirm the presence of carbonate and the absence of nitrate in the interlayer space of the hydrotalcite-like samples. At lower wavenumber values, i.e., 1000-400 cm−1, there are bands characteristic to O-Metal-O vibrations overlapping [2]. To obtain information about the oxidation states and the stereochemistry of the metallic cations, the LDH samples were analyzed by DR-UV-VIS spectroscopy (Fig. 4 ). The spectra present bands attributed to O2−-M2+ charge transfer and d-d transitions characteristic to the octahedral geometry of the transition-metal divalent cations, Ni2+ and Cu2+. For the Ni2+ cations, two spin-allowed transitions, namely: 3A2g(F) → 3T1g(F) and 3A2g(F) → 3T1g(P), were observed. The band specific for 3A2g(F) → 3T1g(F) transition splits due to the spin-orbit coupling [32], and it can be found at 750 nm [33], while the band for 3A2g(F) → 3T1g(P) transition is located at 377 nm. Both bands correspond to Ni2+ in octahedral coordination. For all the samples containing Ni cations, some spin-forbidden transitions 3A2g(F) → 1Eg(D) and 3A2g(F) → 1T2g(D) (bands at ca. 642 and 411 nm, respectively) were also recorded [33]. In contrast with the Ni-rich solids, the Cu2+-rich LDH samples show wider UV-VIS bands due to an increased structural disorder in line with the XRD measurements. In the spectrum of HT-Cu2Al sample, only one spin-allowed, Laporte-forbidden transition is observed 2Eg(D) → 2T2g(D), as expected, which indicates the presence of Cu2+ in the octahedral symmetry [34]. The intensity and width of this band, centered at ca. 770 cm−1, are attributed to the distortion of the octahedral coordination of Cu2+ due to the Jahn-Teller effect. The bands noticed in the UV region for the samples containing both Ni and Cu cations are ascribed to O2− → Mn+ charge transfer transitions [34]. The SEM images (Fig. 5 ) indicated that the samples are not entirely homogenous. Moreover, it seems like small particles are formed and distributed among larger ones. The increase of the nickel content enables the formation of round particles uniformly distributed. It appears that the ovoidal aspect of the particles is more pronounced in the HT-Mg1.2NiaCubAl samples compared to the HT-Mg0.8NicCudAl. In the SEM image of HT-Cu2Al sample, one can see hexagonal platelets and some rod-like particles that are not recurrent in the samples containing nickel and copper. 5.2 Catalytic results The LDH catalysts were tested in the aerobic oxidation-condensation tandem reaction using benzene, toluene and mesitylene as solvents. Toluene and mesitylene have shown to be effective solvents in the tandem reactions explored by Zhou et al. [21]. They, together with benzene, served as adequate solvents in our investigation as well. The alcohol conversions and yields to BPA are displayed in Table 4 . First, we noticed that, compared to the Ce-containing MgAl LDH-graphene oxide composite catalysts used in our previous study [20], the current LDH materials have proven to be more efficient. All the prepared LDH samples exhibited a bifunctional catalytic behavior involving both redox sites, represented by the transition metal cations, and acid-base sites, being, thus, able to promote both the alcohol oxidation and the Knoevenagel condensation in a stepwise way. Except for HT-Cu2Al, the catalysts with higher content of transition metal cations presented higher activity for the oxidation step of the tandem reaction. The low activity of HT-Cu2Al could be related to the sensibly lower value of its specific surface area and to the presence of the malachite impurity. It could also be observed that for a given LDH series, i.e., HT-Mg1.2NiaCubAl or HT-Mg0.8NicCudAl, the catalytic performance decreased with increasing the Cu content at the expense of Ni, whatever the solvent used, suggesting a simple additive effect [35]. Indeed, the catalytic activity in terms of alcohol conversion increased linearly, within the limits of the experimental error, with increasing the Ni/Cu mol ratio in the MgNiCuAl LDH catalysts as seen in Fig. 6 . Moreover, the BPA yield followed the same trend (Fig. S7). The decrease of activity with the increase of Cu content in the catalyst is likely due to the fact that this cation is already in its superior oxidation state and, hence, it is less prone to activate the molecular oxygen in the first step of the process. The highest values of alcohol conversion and BPA yield were obtained with the solid containing only one of the divalent cations, namely HT-Ni2Al, probably due to its ability to activate the molecular oxygen, which was chemisorbed on Ni2+ sites yielding a peroxide type structure. Meanwhile, the benzyl alcohol was transformed into an aluminum alkoxide intermediate, which suffered a hydride abstraction by the neighboring peroxide on the nickel cation being further converted to benzaldehyde according to the mechanism described by Choudary et al. [7]. Notably, this solid also showed the tendency to form spherical aggregates, uniformly distributed, as indicated by the SEM results. The results in Table 4 also show that the catalytic performance of the MgNiCuAl LDH systems was higher for the samples containing lower amounts of Mg and Cu and higher amounts of Ni. Since there were only slight differences between their specific surface areas, this property could not explain the evolution of their catalytic performance. However, good correlations between, on the one hand, the conversion of benzyl alcohol and, on the other hand, the yield of BPA, and the Ni/Mg ratio in the MgNiCuAl LDH catalysts were observed (Fig. 7 ): the higher the Ni/Mg ratio, the higher the catalytic performance. On the other hand, the second step of the tandem reaction, i.e., the Knoevenagel condensation, is expected to be more affected by the acid-base properties of the solid catalysts [36]. Indeed, the yield of the target product (BPA) was shown to decrease with increasing the molar ratio of base-to-acid sites for the MgNiCuAl LDH catalysts (Fig. 8 ). The best BPA yield was observed for the HT-Mg0.8Ni0.8Cu0.4Al system which showed the lowest molar ratio of base-to-acid sites. As reported by Corma et al. [36], there is a cooperation between the acidic and the basic sites in the Knoevenagel condensation reactions of carbonyl compounds with active methylene groups via an ion‐pair mechanism, which consists of the deprotonation of the active methylene group by the basic sites of the catalyst, forming a carbanion. Meanwhile, the carbonyl of the benzaldehyde is activated by the acidic sites, a carbocation being generated. When the carbanion attacks the carbocation, the dehydration reaction takes place and the BPA product is formed. 6 Conclusion Multicationic MgNiCuAl LDH materials were successfully prepared by simple coprecipitation. The XRD studies showed that all the LDH samples had increased crystallinity and confirmed that no other impurities were present in the solids, except for that containing only copper and aluminum. DR-UV-VIS spectroscopy clearly indicated the existence of the octahedral geometry of the divalent transition-metal cations, Ni2+ and Cu2+. The SEM images demonstrated that the samples were not entirely homogenous. For the multicationic LDH samples containing both nickel and copper, irrespective to the nature of solvent used, the benzyl alcohol conversion and the BPA yield increased linearly with the nickel loading, which corresponds to a simple additive effect. In line with this, the NiAl-LDH (HT-Ni2Al) was the most active, while the CuAl LDH (HT-Cu2Al) was the least active system. Notably, HT-Ni2Al showed the largest crystalline domain sizes of the brucite-like layer. For the multicationic MgNiCuAl LDH catalysts, whatever solvent was used, the yield of the target product (BPA) decreased with increasing the molar ratio of base-to-acid sites. The best solvent in all catalytic reactions was benzene. Finally, it can unambiguously be sustained that all the studied LDH materials acted as bifunctional catalysts in the aerobic oxidation-condensation tandem reaction. coredata.dc:description: In this work, the structural and bifunctional catalytic properties of MgNi(Cu)Al layered double hydroxides (LDH) with different molar ratios between the cations were studied. The LDH materials were prepared by co-precipitation and were characterized using X-ray fluorescence (XRF), X-Ray diffraction (XRD), diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier-transform spectroscopy (DRIFT), diffuse reflectance ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy (DR-UV-VIS), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), nitrogen adsorption-desorption and acidity-basicity measurements. They were tested in a one-pot cascade oxidation-Knoevenagel condensation reaction used to synthesize 2-Benzoyl-3-phenylprop-2-enenitrile also known as 2-Benzoyl-3-phenylacrylonitrile (BPA). This involved the benzyl alcohol (BnOH) oxidation under an oxygen atmosphere followed by the Knoevenagel condensation of benzaldehyde with 3-oxo-3-phenylpropanenitrile also known as benzoyl acetonitrile (BzACN). Three different non-polar solvents, i.e., toluene, benzene and 1,3,5-trimethylbenzene (mesitylene), were used as reaction media. For the LDH catalysts containing both nickel and copper, the alcohol conversion and BPA yield increased with Ni/Cu molar ratio. The acid-base properties of the solids and the nature of the solvent strongly influence the reaction performance.
